page.title: 02Ecology
page.content: The island is formed entirely of hard volcanic rock (greenstone) and rises 60 metres above sea level. It is tilted slightly eastwards, resulting in steep cliffs on the west and south-west. The sea has carved a series of rock arches, stacks and caves along the steep west cliffs, and many small inlets along the low lying east coast. Some of these inlets divide the island in three at high tide; the main island, the North Ness, and Rona which is joined to the main island by an iron bridge. A deep steep sided valley, The Black Heugh bisects the main island. The Black Heugh has been dammed at its western end to form a freshwater loch. Beyond the dam is the Mill Door, a fine example of a natural arch. The average rise and fall of the tide is 3 metres.
